stepAnswer: cognition (ways of perceiving and interpreting self, other people, or events), affectivity (the range, intensity, lability, and appropriateness of emotional response), interpersonal functioning, and impulse control
stepTitle: Clients with personality disorders have symptoms in two or more of the following areas:
choices: cognition (ways of perceiving and interpreting self, other people, or events), affectivity (the range, intensity, lability, and appropriateness of emotional response), interpersonal functioning, and impulse control

cognition (ways of perceiving and interpreting self, other people, or events), affectivity (the range, intensity, lability, and appropriateness of emotional response), interpersonal functioning, and impulse control
rigid and inflexible traits that are pervasive and persist over time
unique and enduring patterns of thoughts, emotions, and behaviors that characterize individuals and distinguish them from others
